none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from A. J. Rose, February 12, 1890
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from A. J. Rose, February 12, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value: [Header] State Agricultural and Mechanical College OF TEXAS. (TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.) [Margin: A. J. ROSE, President Board of Directors, Salado Texas. T. M. SCOTT, Agent of the Board, College Station, Texas. LOUIS L. McINNIS, Secretary and Treasurer, College Station, Texas.] Salado, Texas, Feb 12th 1880 Dear Prof McInnis Your favor of 8th came last eve, In reply will say that I will meet you in Austin Wednesday 19th to sign up vouchers can come down Tuesday night or Wednesday night as you prefer I could come down monday night 17th if you prefer this, I very much regretted at not being present at Sugar meeting, I hope it will be conve nient for you to have all the work for the Board redy when we do meet that will be necessary for them to attend to before June, With best wishes for your self & family and progress of the School I am Most Truly A. J. Rose P.S. Glad to hear that the work is running smoothly, sorry to hear of Capt Scotts Illness Hope he will soon be up again

**I've got a fascinating document here: a handwritten letter on official letterhead from the State Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, or what we now know as Texas A&M. I'm carefully transcribing it, paying close attention to every detail, from the letterhead layout to the nuances of the handwriting.**

First, let's break down the header. It's got the formal "State Agricultural and Mechanical College OF TEXAS" in a bold font with "(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)" underneath, in smaller, parenthetical text. Below that, I've got the usual contact information: A.J. Rose, who was President of the Board of Directors, T.M. Scott, as the Agent of the Board, and Louis L. McInnis, the Secretary and Treasurer.

The date line, that's where things get interesting. It reads "Salado, Texas, Feb 12th 1880." Wait, the '0' is handwritten. Given A.J. Rose's tenure as president (1889-1896), the date is likely 1890, but the image shows 1880, so I'm transcribing it as is: **Salado, Texas, Feb 12th 1880**. I've checked and double-checked the handwriting, and it looks like a '0'. We must stay true to the image.

Now, into the body of the letter itself, and I'm capturing everything exactly as it's written. Here's what's there:
**Salado, Texas, Feb 12th 1880**

Dear Prof McInnis
Your favor of 8th came last eve,
In reply will say that I will meet you in
Austin Wednesday 19th to sign up vouchers
can come down Tuesday night or Wednesday
night as you prefer I could come down
monday night 17th if you prefer this,
I very much regretted at not being present
at Sugar meeting, I hope it will be conve
nient for you to have all the work for the Board
redy when we do meet that will be necessary
for them to attend to before June,
With best wishes for your self & family
and progress of the School
I am Most Truly
A. J. Rose

And then, a postscript. I'm seeing:
P.S. Glad to hear that the work is
running smoothly, sorry to hear
of Capt Scotts Illness Hope he
will soon be up again

There is "Wednesday 19th" and "Monday 17th". This is likely 1890 if we are going by the context. However, the date line looks like "1880".

As I'm transcribing, I'm noting any unusual spellings or phrasing. "Favor" is clearly the intended word, even if the "a" looks more like an "o", and "redy" is simply a misspelling of "ready". The capital "I" in "Illness" is clear, and the lack of an apostrophe in "Capt Scotts" is deliberate.

This letter gives a glimpse into the communication of academics and administrators during this period in Texas history.
